q: Which of the following is NOT one of the four tests of a fixture?
e: The four tests of a fixture are: method of attachment, adaptability, intent of the parties, and relationship of the parties. Original cost is not a determining factor.

q: A property owner has the right to use water from a stream that runs through their property. This is an example of:
e: Riparian rights allow property owners to use water from streams or rivers that border or run through their property.

q: Which type of ownership allows for unequal ownership interests?
e: Tenancy in common allows owners to hold unequal interests and does not include automatic rights of survivorship.

q: An easement appurtenant requires:
e: An easement appurtenant requires both a dominant estate (benefited property) and a servient estate (burdened property).

q: The right of survivorship is a characteristic of:
e: Joint tenancy includes the right of survivorship, meaning when one owner dies, their interest automatically passes to the surviving joint tenants.

q: Which of the following would terminate an easement?
o: Merger of the dominant and servient estates
Bankruptcy of the servient estate owner
e: When the dominant and servient estates are merged under one owner, the easement is terminated because you cannot have an easement on your own property.

q: A cooperative apartment owner holds:
o: Shares in the corporation and a proprietary lease
e: In a cooperative, owners hold shares in the corporation that owns the building, along with a proprietary lease for their specific unit.

q: Air rights can be:
e: Air rights can be sold, leased, or transferred separately from the underlying land, subject to zoning and aviation regulations.

q: In a condominium, the owner holds:
o: Fee simple title to the unit and common interest in common areas
e: Condominium owners hold fee simple title to their individual unit and an undivided interest in the common areas.

q: Mineral rights are:
o: Can be severed from surface rights
e: Mineral rights can be severed from surface rights and sold, leased, or transferred separately from the land above.

q: A life estate is:
o: An estate limited by the life of a person
An estate that can be inherited
e: A life estate is a freehold estate that is limited in duration to the life of the life tenant or another named person.

q: Emblements are:
e: Emblements are annual crops produced by cultivation and labor, considered personal property of the tenant even after the lease ends.

q: The highest form of ownership interest in real estate is:
e: Fee simple absolute is the highest form of ownership, providing complete ownership rights with no conditions or limitations.

q: An encroachment is:
o: A legal right to use another's property
A physical intrusion onto another's property
e: An encroachment is the unauthorized physical intrusion of one property owner's improvements onto an adjacent property.

q: Community property is recognized in:
e: Community property is a form of ownership recognized only in certain community property states. New York is a common law state.

q: A lis pendens is:
e: A lis pendens is a notice filed in public records indicating that a lawsuit is pending that may affect title to the property.

q: A time-share owner typically has:
o: The right to use a property for specific time periods
e: Time-share ownership typically grants the right to use a property for specific time periods each year, rather than full ownership.

q: Littoral rights are associated with:
e: Littoral rights are water rights associated with properties adjacent to large bodies of water like lakes, seas, and oceans.

q: Which bundle of rights is NOT typically included in fee simple ownership?
o: Right to dispose of the property
e: The bundle of rights includes possession, control, enjoyment, exclusion, and disposition. It does not include rights over neighboring properties.

q: A deed restriction is:
o: A private limitation on land use
e: Deed restrictions are private limitations on land use imposed by previous owners or developers, running with the land.

q: A zoning variance is:
o: A change to the zoning law
A permitted deviation from zoning requirements
e: A variance is official permission to deviate from current zoning requirements, typically granted when strict application would cause undue hardship.

q: Nonconforming use refers to:
o: A use that violates zoning laws
A use that existed before zoning restrictions
A use that requires a special permit
e: A nonconforming use is a property use that was legal when established but doesn't comply with current zoning laws (grandfathered use).

q: The primary purpose of zoning is to:
o: Promote public health, safety, and welfare
e: Zoning laws are enacted under police power to promote public health, safety, morals, and general welfare of the community.

q: A special use permit allows:
o: A use that is conditionally permitted in a zone
A use that violates zoning laws
e: A special use permit (conditional use permit) allows uses that are acceptable in a zone but require special approval due to their potential impact.

q: Building codes regulate:
e: Building codes regulate construction standards, materials, and safety requirements to protect public health and safety.

q: Spot zoning is:
o: Rezoning a small area differently from surrounding properties
e: Spot zoning involves rezoning a small parcel differently from the surrounding area and may be illegal if it's arbitrary or benefits only one property owner.

q: The power of eminent domain allows government to:
o: Take private property for public use
e: Eminent domain is the government's power to take private property for public use, with just compensation to the owner.

q: Police power includes the government's right to:
o: Regulate land use for public welfare
e: Police power allows government to regulate land use through zoning, building codes, and other regulations to protect public health, safety, and welfare.

q: Environmental impact studies are required for:
e: Environmental impact studies are typically required for major development projects that may significantly affect the environment.

q: A buffer zone is:
o: An area between different land uses
e: A buffer zone is a strip of land that separates different types of land uses, often to reduce conflicts between incompatible uses.

q: Density zoning controls:
e: Density zoning controls the number of dwelling units or amount of development allowed per acre or other unit of area.

q: The Americans with Disabilities Act affects:
e: The ADA requires accessibility modifications in public accommodations and commercial facilities to ensure equal access for people with disabilities.

q: Wetlands are protected by:
e: Wetlands are protected by both federal laws (like the Clean Water Act) and state environmental regulations.

q: A master plan is:
e: A master plan (comprehensive plan) is a long-term guide for community development that serves as the basis for zoning and other land use regulations.

q: Planned Unit Development (PUD) allows:
o: Mixed uses with flexible design standards
e: A PUD allows mixed land uses and flexible design standards in exchange for providing amenities and following an approved master plan.

q: The principle of substitution is the basis for which approach to value?
e: The principle of substitution underlies all three approaches to value, as each assumes a buyer will not pay more than the cost of an equally desirable substitute.

q: In the sales comparison approach, if a comparable property has a feature that the subject property lacks, the adjustment is:
o: Added to the comparable's sale price
Subtracted from the comparable's sale price
Added to the subject property's value
e: If the comparable has a superior feature, its value must be adjusted downward to make it more comparable to the subject property.

q: The capitalization rate is calculated by:
e: Cap rate = Net Operating Income ÷ Value. This shows the rate of return on an investment property.

q: Functional obsolescence refers to:
o: Wear and tear from normal use
Loss in value due to factors outside the property
Outdated design or lack of modern amenities
e: Functional obsolescence is a loss in value due to outdated design, lack of modern amenities, or poor layout that reduces the property's desirability.

q: Which of the following is NOT included in the calculation of net operating income?
e: Debt service (mortgage payments) is not included in NOI calculation. NOI = Gross Income - Operating Expenses (taxes, insurance, management, maintenance, etc.)

q: External obsolescence is caused by:
e: External obsolescence is loss in value caused by factors outside the property, such as economic changes, environmental problems, or neighborhood decline.

q: The cost approach is most reliable for:
e: The cost approach is most reliable for new construction (where cost equals value) and special-purpose properties that rarely sell.

q: Gross rent multiplier (GRM) is calculated by:
e: GRM = Purchase Price ÷ Monthly Gross Rent. It's a quick way to compare rental properties.

q: The principle of highest and best use requires that the use be:
o: Physically possible, legally permissible, financially feasible, and maximally productive
e: Highest and best use must meet all four criteria: physically possible, legally permissible, financially feasible, and maximally productive.

q: Depreciation in real estate appraisal refers to:
o: Loss in value from any cause
e: In appraisal, depreciation means any loss in value from any cause, including physical deterioration, functional obsolescence, and external obsolescence.

q: A Comparative Market Analysis (CMA) is:
e: A CMA is a broker's opinion of value based on analysis of comparable sales, not a formal appraisal.

q: The sales comparison approach is most appropriate for:
e: The sales comparison approach works best when there are adequate, recent, and similar comparable sales available.

q: Accrued depreciation in the cost approach is:
e: In the cost approach: Property Value = Land Value + (Replacement Cost - Accrued Depreciation).

q: The income approach is primarily used for:
e: The income approach is primarily used for valuing income-producing properties like rental properties, office buildings, and shopping centers.

q: Market value is defined as:
o: The highest price a property will bring
The price a willing buyer and seller agree upon
The most probable price under typical market conditions
The assessed value for tax purposes
e: Market value is the most probable price that a property should bring in a competitive and open market under all conditions requisite to a fair sale.

q: In an amortizing loan, early payments consist of:
o: Equal amounts of principal and interest
e: In early payments of an amortizing loan, most of the payment goes to interest, with a smaller portion going to principal. This ratio gradually reverses over time.

q: The loan-to-value ratio on a $300,000 home with a $240,000 loan is:
e: LTV = Loan Amount ÷ Property Value = $240,000 ÷ $300,000 = 80%

q: A borrower's monthly housing payment should not exceed what percentage of gross monthly income under conventional lending guidelines?
e: The front-end ratio (housing payment to gross income) should typically not exceed 28% under conventional lending guidelines.

q: Which of the following is a government-sponsored enterprise?
e: Fannie Mae (FNMA) is a government-sponsored enterprise. FHA, VA, and USDA are government agencies, not GSEs.

q: A balloon payment is:
o: The first payment on a loan
A payment that is larger than other scheduled payments
A penalty payment for late payment
e: A balloon payment is a large payment, usually the final payment, that is significantly larger than the other scheduled payments.

q: Private mortgage insurance (PMI) is typically required when:
e: PMI is typically required on conventional loans when the loan-to-value ratio exceeds 80%.

q: A purchase money mortgage is:
o: Any mortgage used to buy property
A mortgage given by the seller to the buyer
e: A purchase money mortgage is seller financing where the seller acts as the lender and takes back a mortgage from the buyer.

q: The secondary mortgage market:
e: The secondary mortgage market is where existing mortgages are bought and sold, providing liquidity to primary lenders.

q: An adjustable rate mortgage (ARM) has:
o: An interest rate that can change
e: An ARM has an interest rate that can change periodically based on an index, typically resulting in changes to the monthly payment.

q: The Truth in Lending Act requires disclosure of:
e: TILA requires lenders to disclose the APR, finance charges, amount financed, and total payments to help borrowers compare loan costs.

q: A straight note is:
e: A straight note requires periodic interest payments with the principal due in full at maturity (interest-only payments).

q: Points paid at closing are:
e: Points may be tax deductible depending on the circumstances, such as whether they're for a primary residence purchase or refinance.

q: The Equal Credit Opportunity Act prohibits discrimination in lending based on:
o: Race, sex, religion, national origin, age, marital status
e: ECOA prohibits credit discrimination based on race, color, religion, national origin, sex, marital status, age, or receipt of public assistance.

q: A reverse mortgage is available to borrowers who are:
e: Reverse mortgages are available to homeowners who are 62 years of age or older.

q: Assumption of a mortgage means:
o: Taking over the seller's mortgage payments
e: Assumption allows a buyer to take over the seller's existing mortgage, becoming responsible for the remaining payments.

q: In New York, a real estate broker owes fiduciary duties to:
o: No one, since disclosure eliminates fiduciary duties
e: Fiduciary duties are owed only to the party the broker represents (their client), not to customers or other parties in the transaction.

q: Which of the following is NOT a fiduciary duty?
e: The main fiduciary duties are loyalty, disclosure, confidentiality, accounting, reasonable care, and obedience. Warranty is not a fiduciary duty.

q: A broker represents the seller and shows the property to a buyer. The buyer is considered:
e: The buyer would be a customer since the broker represents the seller. A customer receives honest and fair treatment but not fiduciary representation.

q: Dual agency occurs when:
o: Two agents work for the same broker
An agent represents both buyer and seller
An agent works with multiple buyers
e: Dual agency occurs when the same agent or broker represents both the buyer and seller in the same transaction.

q: In New York, when must agency disclosure be made to prospective buyers?
o: At first substantive contact about specific property
Only when an offer is made
e: NY law requires agency disclosure at the first substantive contact about a specific property, which means the first time you discuss a particular property in detail.

q: A subagent is:
o: An agent of the seller's agent
e: A subagent is an agent of the listing broker's client (typically the seller), created when a cooperating broker agrees to represent the seller's interests.

q: The duty of confidentiality requires an agent to:
o: Disclose all information to all parties
Keep the client's confidential information private
e: The duty of confidentiality requires agents to keep their client's confidential information private, even after the agency relationship ends.

q: Puffing in real estate refers to:
e: Puffing refers to exaggerated promotional statements or opinions about a property that are not intended as factual claims.

q: An exclusive right to sell listing gives the broker:
o: The right to sell to anyone
Commission regardless of who sells the property
The right to set the sale price
e: With an exclusive right to sell listing, the broker earns commission regardless of who sells the property during the listing period.

q: The difference between an exclusive agency and exclusive right to sell listing is:
o: Whether the owner can sell without paying commission
e: With exclusive agency, the owner can sell the property themselves without paying commission. With exclusive right to sell, commission is due regardless of who sells.

q: A buyer's agent owes fiduciary duties to:
e: A buyer's agent represents the buyer and owes fiduciary duties to the buyer, not the seller or listing broker.

q: Designated agency in New York allows:
o: One agent to represent both parties
Different agents from the same firm to represent each party
e: Designated agency allows a broker to designate different agents within the firm to represent the buyer and seller in the same transaction.

q: The duty of reasonable care requires an agent to:
o: Use skill and care expected of a competent agent
e: The duty of reasonable care requires agents to use the skill and care expected of a competent real estate professional.

q: Material facts must be disclosed to:
e: Material facts that could affect a party's decision must be disclosed to all parties in the transaction, whether they are clients or customers.

q: An agent's duty of obedience means:
o: Following all client instructions regardless of legality
Following lawful instructions from the client
e: The duty of obedience requires agents to follow lawful instructions from their client, but they cannot follow illegal or unethical instructions.

q: For a contract to be valid, it must have:
o: Offer, acceptance, consideration, and legal purpose
e: A valid contract requires: competent parties, offer and acceptance, consideration, and legal purpose. Writing may be required for enforceability but not validity.

q: Which deed provides the greatest protection to the grantee?
e: A general warranty deed provides the greatest protection because the grantor warrants title against all defects, whether they occurred before or during the grantor's ownership.

q: A voidable contract is one that:
o: Can be canceled by one or both parties
e: A voidable contract is valid but can be canceled by one or both parties under certain circumstances (like fraud, duress, or incapacity).

q: Title insurance protects against:
e: Title insurance protects against financial loss from defects in title that existed before the policy were issued but were unknown at the time.

q: The statute of frauds requires that certain contracts be:
e: The statute of frauds requires certain contracts, including real estate sales contracts, to be in writing to be enforceable.

q: Recording a deed:
e: Recording provides constructive notice to the world of the grantee's ownership claim, but the deed itself transfers ownership.

q: Liquidated damages in a real estate contract:
o: Must equal the full purchase price
e: Liquidated damages are predetermined amounts agreed upon by the parties as compensation for breach of contract, often the earnest money deposit.

q: A warranty deed warrants that:
o: The property is in good condition
The grantor has good title and will defend it
The property will appreciate in value
There are no liens on the property
e: A warranty deed includes the grantor's promise that they have good title and will defend the grantee's title against any claims.

q: Specific performance is:
o: Court order to complete the contract
e: Specific performance is a court order requiring a party to perform their contractual obligations, often used in real estate due to property uniqueness.

q: A quitclaim deed:
o: Transfers whatever interest the grantor has
e: A quitclaim deed transfers whatever interest the grantor has in the property, if any, without warranties about the quality of title.

q: An executory contract is one that:
o: Has not yet been fully performed
e: An executory contract is one where one or both parties have not yet completed their contractual obligations.

q: Chain of title refers to:
e: Chain of title is the chronological history of ownership transfers and other title events affecting a property.

q: A bilateral contract is one where:
o: Only one party makes a promise
e: A bilateral contract involves mutual promises where both parties are obligated to perform (like most real estate purchase contracts).

q: A title search reveals:
e: A title search examines public records to determine ownership history and identify liens, encumbrances, and other matters affecting title.

q: Contingencies in a real estate contract:
o: Allow parties to cancel under specified conditions
e: Contingencies are conditions that must be met for the contract to proceed, allowing cancellation if the conditions aren't satisfied.

q: In New York, a real estate license is required for:
o: An owner selling their own property
An attorney handling a real estate closing
A person who regularly buys and sells property for others for compensation
A property manager managing their own property
e: Anyone who regularly engages in real estate activities for others for compensation must be licensed, with limited exceptions for owners, attorneys in practice, and certain other professionals.

q: A New York real estate salesperson license is valid for:
e: A New York real estate salesperson license is valid for 2 years and must be renewed before expiration.

q: To obtain a New York salesperson license, an applicant must:
e: NY salesperson license requirements include being 18+ years old, completing 75 hours of approved education, and passing the state examination.

q: In New York, all real estate commissions must be paid to:
e: All commissions must be paid to the supervising broker, who then pays the salesperson according to their agreement.

q: A New York broker must maintain transaction records for:
e: New York brokers must maintain transaction records for at least 3 years from the date of the transaction.

q: The New York State Department of State oversees:
e: The NY Department of State Division of Licensing Services oversees real estate licensing, education, and regulation in New York.

q: A salesperson in New York must work under:
e: All salespersons in New York must work under the supervision of a licensed broker who is responsible for their activities.

q: Continuing education in New York requires:
e: New York requires 22.5 hours of continuing education every 2 years for license renewal.

q: The New York Human Rights Law prohibits discrimination in housing based on:
e: The NY Human Rights Law includes additional protected classes beyond federal law, such as lawful source of income, sexual orientation, gender identity, and military status.

q: In New York, property disclosure requirements apply to:
e: New York's Property Condition Disclosure Act applies to the sale of residential real property of one to four dwelling units.

q: A New York real estate broker license is valid for:
e: A New York real estate broker license is valid for 2 years, the same as a salesperson license.

q: In New York, earnest money deposits must:
o: Be deposited in the broker's personal account
Be held in a special escrow account
Be immediately given to the listing agent
e: Earnest money must be held in a special escrow or trust account, separate from the broker's personal or business funds.

q: New York's 'Do Not Call' registry affects:
o: Cold calling to consumers who have registered
e: The Do Not Call registry restricts cold calling to consumers who have registered their phone numbers, with some exceptions for existing business relationships.

q: In New York, a real estate license may be suspended or revoked for:
e: NY licenses may be suspended or revoked for various violations including fraud, failure to complete continuing education, and other license law violations.

q: New York's rent stabilization laws primarily apply in:
o: New York City and certain other municipalities
e: Rent stabilization laws primarily apply in New York City and certain other municipalities, affecting specific types of rental properties.

q: A property sold for $450,000. The broker's commission was 6%, split equally between listing and selling agents. What was the listing agent's commission?
e: Total commission: $450,000 × 6% = $27,000. Split equally: $27,000 ÷ 2 = $13,500 per agent.

q: If a property has an assessed value of $180,000 and the tax rate is 25 mills, what is the annual property tax?
A rectangular lot is 150 feet wide by 200 feet deep. How many acres does it contain?
An agent receives a 3% commission on a $300,000 sale. If the agent splits 60% with the broker, how much does the agent keep?
An investor pays $500,000 for a property and receives $60,000 annual net income. What is the capitalization rate?
e: Cap rate = Net Operating Income ÷ Property Value = $60,000 ÷ $500,000 = 0.12 or 12%.

q: A building cost $800,000 to construct. If it depreciates at 2% per year using straight-line depreciation, what is its value after 5 years?
e: Annual depreciation = $800,000 × 2% = $16,000. After 5 years: $16,000 × 5 = $80,000 total depreciation. $800,000 - $80,000 = $720,000.

q: An income property generates $48,000 annual rent. If the gross rent multiplier is 12, what is the property's estimated value?
e: Monthly rent = $48,000 ÷ 12 = $4,000. Property value = Monthly rent × GRM = $4,000 × 12 = $48,000. Wait, this is wrong. Property value = Annual rent × GRM = $48,000 × 12 = $576,000.

q: A loan has a principal balance of $200,000 at 5% annual interest. What is the monthly interest payment?
e: Annual interest = $200,000 × 5% = $10,000. Monthly interest = $10,000 ÷ 12 = $833.33.

q: A property is purchased for $400,000 and sold 3 years later for $460,000. What was the annual rate of appreciation?
A square lot contains 2 acres. What is the length of each side?
e: 2 acres = 2 × 43,560 = 87,120 sq ft. For a square: side length = √87,120 = 295 feet.

q: A borrower gets a $300,000 loan at 6% interest for 30 years. If the monthly payment is $1,799, how much interest is paid in the first month?
e: Monthly interest rate = 6% ÷ 12 = 0.5%. First month interest = $300,000 × 0.5% = $1,500.

q: A property has a potential gross income of $120,000. With a 5% vacancy rate and $8,000 in operating expenses, what is the net operating income?
An appraiser estimates that a building will last 40 years. If it's currently 10 years old, what percentage of its useful life remains?
e: Remaining life = 40 - 10 = 30 years. Percentage remaining = 30 ÷ 40 = 75%.

q: A buyer wants to purchase a $350,000 home with a 90% LTV loan. How much cash must the buyer provide for the down payment?
An investment property purchased for $200,000 generates $24,000 annual rent. After expenses of $6,000, what is the cash-on-cash return?
A triangular lot has a base of 100 feet and a height of 150 feet. What is its area in square feet?
e: Area of triangle = (base × height) ÷ 2 = (100 × 150) ÷ 2 = 7,500 sq ft.

q: Property taxes of $4,800 are paid annually in advance on January 1. If a property closes on September 1, how much does the buyer owe the seller?
e: Sept 1 - Dec 31 = 4 months. Monthly tax = $4,800 ÷ 12 = $400. Buyer owes seller: $400 × 4 = $1,600.

q: A salesperson earns $72,000 annually from a 3% commission rate. What was the total dollar volume of sales?
e: Sales volume = Commission earned ÷ Commission rate = $72,000 ÷ 3% = $2,400,000.

q: A property's value increases from $250,000 to $275,000. What is the percentage increase?
An investor pays $80,000 cash and gets a $320,000 mortgage to buy a $400,000 property. What is the loan-to-value ratio?
e: LTV = Loan amount ÷ Property value = $320,000 ÷ $400,000 = 80%.

q: A rectangular property is 300 feet by 200 feet. If similar properties sell for $2 per square foot, what is this property's estimated value?
A property has operating expenses of $15,000 and a net operating income of $45,000. What is the gross income?
e: Gross Income = NOI + Operating Expenses = $45,000 + $15,000 = $60,000.

q: An agent splits commission 70/30 with their broker. On a $500,000 sale with 6% total commission, how much does the agent receive if they represent the buyer?
e: Total commission = $500,000 × 6% = $30,000. Buyer agent gets half = $15,000. Agent keeps 70%: $15,000 × 70% = $10,500.

q: A property appreciates 4% annually. If it's worth $300,000 today, what will it be worth in 3 years?
e: With compound appreciation: $300,000 × (1.04)³ = $300,000 × 1.124864 = $337,459, approximately $337,493.

q: A percentage lease is commonly used for:
e: Percentage leases, where rent is based on a percentage of the tenant's gross sales, are commonly used for retail properties.

q: A lease that automatically renews for successive periods is called:
e: A periodic tenancy automatically renews for successive periods (month-to-month, year-to-year) until terminated by proper notice.

q: In New York, security deposits for residential rentals:
e: In New York, security deposits for residential rentals generally cannot exceed one month's rent.

q: A net lease requires the tenant to pay:
o: Base rent plus some or all operating expenses
e: In a net lease, the tenant pays base rent plus some or all operating expenses such as taxes, insurance, and maintenance.

q: The warranty of habitability requires landlords to:
e: The warranty of habitability requires landlords to maintain rental properties in safe, sanitary, and livable condition.

q: A property manager's first duty is to:
e: A property manager's primary fiduciary duty is to follow the property owner's lawful instructions and act in the owner's best interests.

q: Rent control laws typically:
e: Rent control laws typically limit the amount and frequency of rent increases for covered properties.

q: An escalation clause in a lease allows for:
o: Rent increases based on specified criteria
e: An escalation clause allows for rent increases based on specified criteria such as inflation, operating cost increases, or predetermined schedules.

q: The legal process to remove a tenant who has breached their lease is called:
e: Eviction is the legal process by which a landlord removes a tenant who has violated the lease terms or failed to pay rent.

q: A gross lease means the tenant pays:
o: Base rent plus all operating expenses
A fixed rent with landlord paying operating expenses
e: In a gross lease, the tenant pays a fixed rent amount and the landlord pays all or most operating expenses.

q: Rent stabilization differs from rent control in that it:
e: Rent stabilization allows for regulated rent increases according to guidelines, while rent control typically freezes rents at specific levels.

q: A holdover tenant is one who:
e: A holdover tenant is one who remains in possession of the property after their lease has expired.

q: The Americans with Disabilities Act affects property management by requiring:
o: All units to be wheelchair accessible
Special rental rates for disabled tenants
e: The ADA requires property managers to make reasonable accommodations for disabled tenants and ensure accessibility in common areas.

q: A management agreement should specify:
o: Only the term of the agreement
e: A comprehensive management agreement should specify the manager's duties, compensation, term, authority, and other important terms.

q: Triple net lease (NNN) means the tenant pays:
o: Base rent plus taxes, insurance, and maintenance
e: In a triple net lease, the tenant pays base rent plus all three major expense categories: taxes, insurance, and maintenance/repairs.

q: Houses built before what year are presumed to contain lead-based paint?
e: Houses built before 1978 are presumed to contain lead-based paint, triggering federal disclosure requirements.

q: Which environmental hazard is odorless and colorless but can cause lung cancer?
e: Radon is a naturally occurring radioactive gas that is odorless and colorless but is the second leading cause of lung cancer.

q: Asbestos was commonly used in building materials until:
e: Asbestos was commonly used in building materials until around 1980, when its health hazards became widely recognized.

q: Underground storage tanks (USTs) are a concern because they may:
o: Leak petroleum products into soil and groundwater
e: USTs are primarily a concern because they may leak petroleum products, gasoline, or other hazardous substances into soil and groundwater.

q: The federal Superfund law (CERCLA) addresses:
e: CERCLA (Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act) addresses the cleanup of contaminated hazardous waste sites.

q: Mold problems in buildings are typically caused by:
e: Mold problems are typically caused by excess moisture from leaks, flooding, poor ventilation, or high humidity.

q: PCBs (polychlorinated biphenyls) were commonly found in:
o: Electrical transformers and fluorescent light ballasts
e: PCBs were commonly used in electrical equipment like transformers and fluorescent light ballasts before being banned due to health concerns.

q: The disclosure of lead-based paint hazards is required for:
e: Federal law requires disclosure of lead-based paint hazards in residential properties built before 1978.

q: Friable asbestos is particularly dangerous because it:
o: Can easily release fibers into the air
e: Friable asbestos is dangerous because it can be easily crumbled or pulverized, releasing harmful fibers into the air.

q: Carbon monoxide is dangerous because it:
o: Prevents oxygen from reaching body tissues
e: Carbon monoxide is dangerous because it binds to hemoglobin, preventing oxygen from reaching body tissues and potentially causing death.

q: Formaldehyde in buildings is commonly found in:
e: Formaldehyde is commonly found in pressed wood products (particleboard, plywood) and some types of insulation.

q: The Clean Water Act regulates:
e: The Clean Water Act regulates the discharge of pollutants into surface waters and wetlands to maintain water quality.

q: Brownfields are:
o: Previously contaminated commercial or industrial sites
e: Brownfields are previously contaminated commercial or industrial sites that may require environmental cleanup before redevelopment.

q: Sick building syndrome refers to:
o: Health problems related to poor indoor air quality
e: Sick building syndrome refers to health problems experienced by building occupants that are related to poor indoor air quality.

q: An environmental site assessment (Phase I) typically involves:
o: Review of records and visual inspection
e: A Phase I environmental site assessment involves reviewing historical records, conducting interviews, and performing a visual site inspection to identify potential contamination.

q: Under the Fair Housing Act, which of the following is NOT a protected class?
e: Age is not a protected class under the Federal Fair Housing Act. The protected classes are race, color, religion, sex, handicap, familial status, and national origin.

q: The Fair Housing Act prohibits discrimination in:
o: Sale and rental of housing only
e: The Fair Housing Act prohibits discrimination in all housing-related activities including sales, rentals, financing, advertising, and brokerage services.

q: Steering refers to:
o: Directing people to or away from certain areas based on protected class
e: Steering is the illegal practice of directing people toward or away from certain areas based on their membership in a protected class.

q: Blockbusting involves:
o: Encouraging sales by suggesting demographic changes will affect property values
e: Blockbusting is the illegal practice of encouraging property sales by suggesting that demographic changes will negatively affect property values.

q: Redlining refers to:
o: Refusing to make loans in certain areas
e: Redlining is the discriminatory practice of refusing to provide services (like loans or insurance) to residents of certain areas, often based on race or ethnicity.

q: Reasonable accommodations under fair housing law require:
o: Changes that don't create undue financial burden
e: Reasonable accommodations are changes in rules, policies, or services that don't create an undue financial or administrative burden on the housing provider.

q: The Fair Housing Act applies to:
e: The Fair Housing Act applies to most housing, with limited exemptions for owner-occupied buildings with 4 or fewer units and single-family homes sold without a broker.

q: Familial status protection covers:
o: Families with children under 18 and pregnant women
e: Familial status protection covers families with children under 18 and pregnant women, regardless of marital status.

q: Housing for older persons may exclude families with children if:
o: The building is over 10 years old
It meets specific age requirements (55+ or 62+)
e: Housing for older persons may exclude families with children if it meets specific requirements, such as 80% of units occupied by persons 55+ or exclusively for persons 62+.

q: Sexual harassment in housing is prohibited under:
o: The Fair Housing Act's sex discrimination provisions
e: Sexual harassment in housing is prohibited under the Fair Housing Act's prohibition against sex discrimination.

q: A real estate agent's primary duty is to:
o: Close as many deals as possible
Act in the client's best interests
e: A real estate agent's primary duty is to act in their client's best interests while following all applicable laws and regulations.

q: Commingling of funds refers to:
o: Mixing client funds with personal funds
e: Commingling is the illegal practice of mixing client funds (like earnest money) with personal or business operating funds.

q: A dual agent must:
o: Remain neutral and disclose the dual agency
Refuse to work with both parties
e: A dual agent must remain neutral, disclose the dual agency relationship, and obtain consent from both parties.

q: An agent learns that a property has a structural defect. The agent should:
o: Only tell the buyer if asked
Disclose the material fact to all parties
e: Material facts that could affect a party's decision must be disclosed to all parties in the transaction.

q: Pocket listings are:
e: Pocket listings are properties that agents market privately without entering them into the Multiple Listing Service (MLS).

q: A licensee receives multiple offers on a listed property. The licensee should:
o: Present all offers to the seller
Choose the best offer for the seller
e: All offers must be presented to the seller in a timely manner, allowing the seller to make informed decisions.

q: Self-dealing occurs when an agent:
o: Has a personal interest in the transaction
e: Self-dealing occurs when an agent has a personal financial interest in a transaction, which must be disclosed to all parties.

q: Kickbacks in real estate transactions are:
e: Kickbacks are prohibited under the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA) and can result in fines and penalties.

q: An agent's duty of loyalty means:
e: The duty of loyalty requires agents to put their client's legitimate interests above their own and avoid conflicts of interest.

q: Confidential information learned during representation:
o: Must be shared with all parties
Should remain confidential even after the relationship ends
Can be used for future marketing
e: Confidential information must remain confidential even after the agency relationship ends, unless disclosure is required by law.

q: A buyer's agent learns the seller will accept less than the asking price. The agent should:
o: Use it to negotiate a better deal
e: This is confidential information about the seller that should not be disclosed to the buyer, as it would violate the listing agent's duty to the seller.

q: Net listings are:
e: Net listings, where the agent keeps everything above a specified net amount to the seller, are prohibited in many states due to potential conflicts of interest.

q: An agent discovers that a competing agent is providing false information about a property. The agent should:
o: Report the violation to appropriate authorities
Use it as a competitive advantage
e: Violations of professional standards or laws should be reported to the appropriate regulatory authorities or professional organizations.

q: Post-closing possession by the seller:
o: Requires proper documentation and insurance considerations
e: Post-closing possession arrangements require proper documentation, insurance considerations, and clear terms to protect all parties.

q: Continuing education requirements exist to:
o: Keep licensees current with laws and practices
Limit the number of active agents
e: Continuing education requirements ensure that licensed professionals stay current with changing laws, regulations, and industry practices.

q: A licensee's responsibility for supervising unlicensed assistants includes:
o: Ensuring they don't perform activities requiring a license
e: Licensees must ensure that unlicensed assistants don't perform activities that require a real estate license, such as negotiating or showing properties.

q: Trust accounts for client funds must:
o: Be kept separate from business operating funds
Be invested in the stock market
Only be used for large transactions
e: Trust accounts must be kept separate from business operating funds and used only for holding client funds like earnest money deposits.

q: Recordkeeping requirements for real estate transactions:
o: Must be maintained for a specified period
e: Real estate professionals must maintain transaction records for a specified period as required by state law, typically 3-6 years.

q: A licensee facing a complaint should:
e: When facing a complaint, licensees should respond promptly, professionally, and truthfully to regulatory authorities while seeking appropriate guidance.

q: Professional liability insurance:
o: Protects against errors and omissions claims
e: Professional liability (errors and omissions) insurance protects real estate professionals against claims arising from professional mistakes or negligence.

q: Which type of ownership allows for unequal ownership interests?
e: Tenancy in common allows owners to hold unequal interests and does not include automatic rights of survivorship.

q: An easement appurtenant requires:
e: An easement appurtenant requires both a dominant estate (benefited property) and a servient estate (burdened property).

q: The right of survivorship is a characteristic of:
e: Joint tenancy includes the right of survivorship, meaning when one owner dies, their interest automatically passes to the surviving joint tenants.

q: Which of the following would terminate an easement?
o: Merger of the dominant and servient estates
Bankruptcy of the servient estate owner
e: When the dominant and servient estates are merged under one owner, the easement is terminated because you cannot have an easement on your own property.

q: A cooperative apartment owner holds:
o: Shares in the corporation and a proprietary lease
e: In a cooperative, owners hold shares in the corporation that owns the building, along with a proprietary lease for their specific unit.

q: Air rights can be:
e: Air rights can be sold, leased, or transferred separately from the underlying land, subject to zoning and aviation regulations.

q: In a condominium, the owner holds:
o: Fee simple title to the unit and common interest in common areas
e: Condominium owners hold fee simple title to their individual unit and an undivided interest in the common areas.

q: Mineral rights are:
o: Can be severed from surface rights
e: Mineral rights can be severed from surface rights and sold, leased, or transferred separately from the land above.

q: A zoning variance is:
o: A change to the zoning law
A permitted deviation from zoning requirements
e: A variance is official permission to deviate from current zoning requirements, typically granted when strict application would cause undue hardship.

q: Nonconforming use refers to:
o: A use that violates zoning laws
A use that existed before zoning restrictions
A use that requires a special permit
e: A nonconforming use is a property use that was legal when established but doesn't comply with current zoning laws (grandfathered use).

q: The primary purpose of zoning is to:
o: Promote public health, safety, and welfare
e: Zoning laws are enacted under police power to promote public health, safety, morals, and general welfare of the community.

q: The power of eminent domain allows government to:
o: Take private property for public use
e: Eminent domain is the government's power to take private property for public use, with just compensation to the owner.

q: Planned Unit Development (PUD) allows:
o: Mixed uses with flexible design standards
e: A PUD allows mixed land uses and flexible design standards in exchange for providing amenities and following an approved master plan.

q: The principle of substitution is the basis for which approach to value?
e: The principle of substitution underlies all three approaches to value, as each assumes a buyer will not pay more than the cost of an equally desirable substitute.

q: In the sales comparison approach, if a comparable property has a feature that the subject property lacks, the adjustment is:
o: Added to the comparable's sale price
Subtracted from the comparable's sale price
Added to the subject property's value
e: If the comparable has a superior feature, its value must be adjusted downward to make it more comparable to the subject property.

q: The capitalization rate is calculated by:
e: Cap rate = Net Operating Income ÷ Value. This shows the rate of return on an investment property.

q: Functional obsolescence refers to:
o: Wear and tear from normal use
Loss in value due to factors outside the property
Outdated design or lack of modern amenities
e: Functional obsolescence is a loss in value due to outdated design, lack of modern amenities, or poor layout that reduces the property's desirability.

q: Which of the following is NOT included in the calculation of net operating income?
e: Debt service (mortgage payments) is not included in NOI calculation. NOI = Gross Income - Operating Expenses (taxes, insurance, management, maintenance, etc.)

q: In an amortizing loan, early payments consist of:
o: Equal amounts of principal and interest
e: In early payments of an amortizing loan, most of the payment goes to interest, with a smaller portion going to principal. This ratio gradually reverses over time.

q: The loan-to-value ratio on a $300,000 home with a $240,000 loan is:
e: LTV = Loan Amount ÷ Property Value = $240,000 ÷ $300,000 = 80%

q: A borrower's monthly housing payment should not exceed what percentage of gross monthly income under conventional lending guidelines?
e: The front-end ratio (housing payment to gross income) should typically not exceed 28% under conventional lending guidelines.

q: Which of the following is a government-sponsored enterprise?
e: Fannie Mae (FNMA) is a government-sponsored enterprise. FHA, VA, and USDA are government agencies, not GSEs.

q: A balloon payment is:
o: The first payment on a loan
A payment that is larger than other scheduled payments
A penalty payment for late payment
e: A balloon payment is a large payment, usually the final payment, that is significantly larger than the other scheduled payments.

q: In New York, a real estate broker owes fiduciary duties to:
o: No one, since disclosure eliminates fiduciary duties
e: Fiduciary duties are owed only to the party the broker represents (their client), not to customers or other parties in the transaction.

q: Which of the following is NOT a fiduciary duty?
e: The main fiduciary duties are loyalty, disclosure, confidentiality, accounting, reasonable care, and obedience. Warranty is not a fiduciary duty.

q: A broker represents the seller and shows the property to a buyer. The buyer is considered:
e: The buyer would be a customer since the broker represents the seller. A customer receives honest and fair treatment but not fiduciary representation.

q: Dual agency occurs when:
o: Two agents work for the same broker
An agent represents both buyer and seller
An agent works with multiple buyers
e: Dual agency occurs when the same agent or broker represents both the buyer and seller in the same transaction.

q: In New York, when must agency disclosure be made to prospective buyers?
o: At first substantive contact about specific property
Only when an offer is made
e: NY law requires agency disclosure at the first substantive contact about a specific property, which means the first time you discuss a particular property in detail.

q: For a contract to be valid, it must have:
o: Offer, acceptance, consideration, and legal purpose
e: A valid contract requires: competent parties, offer and acceptance, consideration, and legal purpose. Writing may be required for enforceability but not validity.

q: Which deed provides the greatest protection to the grantee?
e: A general warranty deed provides the greatest protection because the grantor warrants title against all defects, whether they occurred before or during the grantor's ownership.

q: Title insurance protects against:
e: Title insurance protects against financial loss from defects in title that existed before the policy were issued but were unknown at the time.

q: The statute of frauds requires that certain contracts be:
e: The statute of frauds requires certain contracts, including real estate sales contracts, to be in writing to be enforceable.

q: A quitclaim deed:
o: Transfers whatever interest the grantor has
e: A quitclaim deed transfers whatever interest the grantor has in the property, if any, without warranties about the quality of title.

q: In New York, a real estate license is required for:
o: An owner selling their own property
An attorney handling a real estate closing
A person who regularly buys and sells property for others for compensation
A property manager managing their own property
e: Anyone who regularly engages in real estate activities for others for compensation must be licensed, with limited exceptions for owners, attorneys in practice, and certain other professionals.

q: A New York real estate salesperson license is valid for:
e: A New York real estate salesperson license is valid for 2 years and must be renewed before expiration.

q: To obtain a New York salesperson license, an applicant must:
e: NY salesperson license requirements include being 18+ years old, completing 75 hours of approved education, and passing the state examination.

q: In New York, all real estate commissions must be paid to:
e: All commissions must be paid to the supervising broker, who then pays the salesperson according to their agreement.

q: Continuing education in New York requires:
e: New York requires 22.5 hours of continuing education every 2 years for license renewal.

q: A property sold for $450,000. The broker's commission was 6%, split equally between listing and selling agents. What was the listing agent's commission?
e: Total commission: $450,000 × 6% = $27,000. Split equally: $27,000 ÷ 2 = $13,500 per agent.

q: If a property has an assessed value of $180,000 and the tax rate is 25 mills, what is the annual property tax?
A rectangular lot is 150 feet wide by 200 feet deep. How many acres does it contain?
An agent receives a 3% commission on a $300,000 sale. If the agent splits 60% with the broker, how much does the agent keep?
An investor pays $500,000 for a property and receives $60,000 annual net income. What is the capitalization rate?
e: Cap rate = Net Operating Income ÷ Property Value = $60,000 ÷ $500,000 = 0.12 or 12%.

q: A percentage lease is commonly used for:
e: Percentage leases, where rent is based on a percentage of the tenant's gross sales, are commonly used for retail properties.

q: A lease that automatically renews for successive periods is called:
e: A periodic tenancy automatically renews for successive periods (month-to-month, year-to-year) until terminated by proper notice.

q: In New York, security deposits for residential rentals:
e: In New York, security deposits for residential rentals generally cannot exceed one month's rent.

q: A net lease requires the tenant to pay:
o: Base rent plus some or all operating expenses
e: In a net lease, the tenant pays base rent plus some or all operating expenses such as taxes, insurance, and maintenance.

q: The warranty of habitability requires landlords to:
e: The warranty of habitability requires landlords to maintain rental properties in safe, sanitary, and livable condition.

q: Houses built before what year are presumed to contain lead-based paint?
e: Houses built before 1978 are presumed to contain lead-based paint, triggering federal disclosure requirements.

q: Which environmental hazard is odorless and colorless but can cause lung cancer?
e: Radon is a naturally occurring radioactive gas that is odorless and colorless but is the second leading cause of lung cancer.

q: Asbestos was commonly used in building materials until:
e: Asbestos was commonly used in building materials until around 1980, when its health hazards became widely recognized.

q: Underground storage tanks (USTs) are a concern because they may:
o: Leak petroleum products into soil and groundwater
e: USTs are primarily a concern because they may leak petroleum products, gasoline, or other hazardous substances into soil and groundwater.

q: Mold problems in buildings are typically caused by:
e: Mold problems are typically caused by excess moisture from leaks, flooding, poor ventilation, or high humidity.

q: Under the Fair Housing Act, which of the following is NOT a protected class?
e: Age is not a protected class under the Federal Fair Housing Act. The protected classes are race, color, religion, sex, handicap, familial status, and national origin.

q: The Fair Housing Act prohibits discrimination in:
o: Sale and rental of housing only
e: The Fair Housing Act prohibits discrimination in all housing-related activities including sales, rentals, financing, advertising, and brokerage services.

q: Steering refers to:
o: Directing people to or away from certain areas based on protected class
e: Steering is the illegal practice of directing people toward or away from certain areas based on their membership in a protected class.

q: Blockbusting involves:
o: Encouraging sales by suggesting demographic changes will affect property values
e: Blockbusting is the illegal practice of encouraging property sales by suggesting that demographic changes will negatively affect property values.

q: Familial status protection covers:
o: Families with children under 18 and pregnant women
e: Familial status protection covers families with children under 18 and pregnant women, regardless of marital status.

q: A real estate agent's primary duty is to:
o: Close as many deals as possible
Act in the client's best interests
e: A real estate agent's primary duty is to act in their client's best interests while following all applicable laws and regulations.

q: Commingling of funds refers to:
o: Mixing client funds with personal funds
e: Commingling is the illegal practice of mixing client funds (like earnest money) with personal or business operating funds.

q: A dual agent must:
o: Remain neutral and disclose the dual agency
Refuse to work with both parties
e: A dual agent must remain neutral, disclose the dual agency relationship, and obtain consent from both parties.

q: An agent learns that a property has a structural defect. The agent should:
o: Only tell the buyer if asked
Disclose the material fact to all parties
e: Material facts that could affect a party's decision must be disclosed to all parties in the transaction.

q: A licensee receives multiple offers on a listed property. The licensee should:
o: Present all offers to the seller
Choose the best offer for the seller
e: All offers must be presented to the seller in a timely manner, allowing the seller to make informed decisions.
